awd_abstract_narration:
The City Career College (C3) project forms a partnership between Ranken Technical College, the St. Louis Public Schools, and industry to create clearly defined, accelerated career pathways to employment in advanced manufacturing and information technology. Over the next decade, over half of nearly 3.5 million manufacturing jobs are expected to remain unfilled due to retirements, changing technology, global competition and the relatively low number of students pursuing science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) careers. The talent shortage impacts two fields in particular: Advanced Manufacturing and Information Technology (IT). In a study recently conducted by the Manufacturing Institute, 82% of manufacturers reported a moderate or serious skills gap, and 74% of manufacturers reported that the skills gap had a negative impact their ability to expand. A similar gap exists in the IT industry. To bridge this gap, apprenticeships offer a promising method for ensuring that students have the skills required needed to transition into high-demand professions. They offer a viable alternative to a four-year college degree. Traditionally associated with the construction trades, apprenticeships are evolving to include high-growth industries such as IT, advanced manufacturing and healthcare, enabling students/employees to "learn while they earn" and study first-hand under the guidance of more experienced practitioners.

C3 serves the national interest by creating a pipeline to these high-demand professions. Students will enter the pipeline through informal summer STEM learning activities at secondary schools to engage them in the targeted career paths. C3 will assess and prepare students to participate in the City Career College, where they will attend classes at Ranken Technical College and earn degree credit throughout their senior year of high school. Career counselors, mentors and tutors will guide the students and connect them directly with employers though paid internships, job shadowing and on-campus microenterprises. By the end of the first year of college, participants will have earned an associate degree and be ready for employment. C3 will evaluate the impact of cultivation and acceleration on student recruitment and retention practices and efforts, examine techniques to attract minority and under-represented students, and assess the impact of frequent interaction of students with faculty and industry advisors/mentors. C3 will create a model that has the potential to transform workforce preparation on a broad scale.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Overview

The City Career College (C3) program sequence has been designed to explore whether establishing a clearly defined, accelerated career pathway results in increased employment opportunities for students in the advanced manufacturing and information technology fields.

The planned general sequence of activities includes:

 9th - 11th grade students participate in existing pipeline activities.

 Identify and invite prospective 9th graders to participate in a preparatory track.

 At the end of the 10th grade, students will be recruited, tested and enrolled in the program.

 Participating 11th grade C3 students receive intensive tutoring, career awareness and planning activities

 Remedial/Preparatory classes available during the 11th grade and during the summer before the 12th grade.

 Students complete a dual enrollment year during the 12th grade.

 Students attend full-day classes on the Ranken campus

 Secondary classes that cannot be covered by an existing college class will be offered by the school district on the Ranken campus or via online learning through SLPS

 Students may travel back to their home schools to participate in afterschool activities such as sports and/or band.

 Students adhere to academic requirements, including a strict work ethic component, and are graded on traits such as appearance, attendance, professionalism, and teamwork.

Broader Impacts

Ranken's C3 project is designed to achieve the following broader impacts:

 improve student retention and success,

 identify specific recruitment techniques to attract minority and under-represented students,

 improve recruitment, retention, persistence and career placement efforts

Findings and Recommendations

Project Strengths

 The results indicate the C3 dual enrollment model can be successfully applied to a wide range of different technical programs.

 Ranken has built a broad set of strong industry partnerships and support.

 Ranken's Microenterprises (paid work experiences located on Ranken's campus in industry equipped work cells) is a strong example of such partnerships and a valuable resource for attracting and developing successful students.

 Ranken has built a strong K-12 pipeline of students from previous projects

 The project has allowed Ranken to expand their reach to other school systems and helped build dual enrollment partnerships with other school districts.

 Retention rates showed steady improvements each year of the project eventually surpassing the 68% retention rate for the entire student population

Lessons Learned

 Getting prospective students on campus for firsthand exposure to technologies was the most effective method for helping build career awareness. Shadow-a-Tech Day was the most mentioned activity for helping build career awareness.

 Recruiting activities that brought students onto campus also had the most impact of student enrollment.

 Students were aware of career options and pathways in general but not necessarily the specific skills needed or what a person in a specific career field actually does.

 Career awareness seems to be broad and generic among students. A "good job with a good salary" is a primary career goal of most students.

 Students tend to emphasize the financial aspects of career opportunities over other factors

 Retention rates nearly doubled for students from year one to year two of their experience. This highlights the importance of emphasizing support services in the first year of the students' experience.

 Obtaining a credential was more important to the parent than to the student. Student just wants to get the technical skills that lead to employment. Several students completed all of the requirements of the technical program but did not complete the general education

 Work based learning experiences had the most impact on employment

Project Challenges and Gaps

 Prospective students are aware of the broad career opportunities available through Ranken but not specific career options and their educational requirements 

 The smaller cohorts in a project like Ranken's C3 and the smaller number of students responding provide minimal evaluation data and make it difficult to identify any broad trends

 Students are often unable or reluctant to identify any barriers or obstacles they encounter

 54% of faculty perceived DE students to be much or somewhat worse in their ability to do college work compared to traditional students, indicating that barriers do indeed exist.

 COVID-19 pandemic had a significant negative impact on recruiting students into the program, especially during 2020-2021.

Recommendations and Next Steps

 Ranken could strengthen the impact of the on-campus recruitment activities by adding a longer orientation or boot camp experience for potential students, giving them an opportunity to spend up to a week on campus versus a single day. This would allow them to better see how the classroom and hands-on labs would be integrated in a full program.

 While readily available, retention services were not widely utilized or sought out. Impact could have possibly been greater if Ranken had been more proactive in this area. 


Last Modified: 11/01/2022
Modified by: Donald Pohl
